facts.text: During the year 1948 the appellant made a profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9. It paid 24 3/4 per cent. dividend on ordinary shares, being the maximum that could be paid under the Public Companies Limitation of Dividend Ordinance of 1948 and also paid to the workers their full share of bonus at annas 4 in a rupee of their basic earnings.
During the year 1949 the selling rates for cloth and yarn were controlled by the Government and were approximately 4 per cent. below those obtained in 1948.
The basic wages were increased from the 1st December, 1948, by order of the Government of Uttar Pradesh and the total wages paid were therefore higher than those in the previous year.
There was moreover indiscipline amongst the workers and production suffered. There was a strike in the month of October and the mills were closed for nearly a month.
Further the management were unable to secure cotton which resulted in the curtailment of the working hours.
As a result of all these circumstances the appellant suffered a trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10.

A sum of Rs. 2,50,000 being the excess reserve for taxation was written back and a sum of Rs. 10,01,871-13-5 being the amount of reserve transferred from the investment account was also brought in. An aggregate sum of Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 was thus brought into the balance-sheet by these two transfers.
The trading loss was deducted from this amount leaving a credit balance of Rs. 7,49,308-11-7 and that amount was shown as the profit for the year 1949 in the balance-sheet for that year.
The balance which had been brought forward from the previous year was added thereto and a dividend of 24 3/4 per cent. was paid to the ordinary shareholders.

The appellant also paid ex gratia to the workmen bonus at the rate of annas 2 per rupee of their basic earnings making it clear by their notification dated the 7th April, 1950, that the directors had sanctioned the payment at that rate in spite of the appellant having suffered a trading loss for the year, that it was being paid entirely at the discretion of the appellant and was not related to or connected with any contract of employment of any worker.

On the 4th May, 1950, the Secretary of the respondent Union petitioned to the Provincial Conciliation Officer (Textile) that there was more production in 1949 than in 1948, that there was no reason to hold that the profit in 1949 was less than in the previous year and that the rate of bonus was wrongly reduced and asked that bonus for 1949 should also be paid at the rate of annas 4 per rupee.
The industrial dispute which thus arose was referred for enquiry and recording of an award to the Regional Conciliation Board (Textile), Kanpur.
The Conciliation Board by a majority decision repelled the contention of the appellant and awarded the payment of bonus at annas 4 per rupee.
On an appeal taken by the appellant to the Industrial Court (Textiles and Hosiery), Kanpur, the Industrial Court accepted the contention of the appellant, allowed the appeal and set aside the award.

The respondent thereupon appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal which substantially agreed with the Industrial Court on questions of fact as well as the general position in law but imported considerations of social justice and treating this as a special case where social justice would demand that labour should have bonus for the year where for that very year capital had not only a reasonable return but much in excess of that, allowed the appeal and directed the appellant to pay to the workmen bonus at the rate of annas 4 per rupee within six weeks of their decision.
The appellant filed this appeal against that decision after obtaining special leave from this Court.

Both the Industrial Court as well as the Labour Appellate Tribunal found as a fact that there was a trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 during the year 1949 and also that the dividend of 24 3/4 per cent. to the ordinary shareholders was distributed after transferring the aggregate sum of Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 from the reserves.

legal_issues.text: whether the workers are entitled to the payment of a bonus in spite of the employer having worked at a loss during the year
whether the workers have any right, title or interest in the reserves and the undistributed profits of the previous years

petitioner_arguments.text: There was a trading loss in 1949, bonus only payable from profits of that year, no entitlement despite transfers from reserves.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bonus not deferred wage; only from current year profits

respondent_arguments.text: More production in 1949 than 1948, no reason profits less, bonus should be annas 4 per rupee like previous year.
Social justice demands bonus where capital had excess return.

court_reasoning.text: Bonus is a boon or gift over and above what is nominally due; primary meaning is ex gratia, secondary in industrial relations as sharing profits from joint contribution of capital and labour.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim for bonus only if profits earned that year from joint contribution; no basis if trading loss.

court_reasoning.text: Workers have no right, title or interest in reserves or undistributed profits of previous years; those belong to shareholders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer from reserves does not create entitlement to bonus when current year shows loss.

court_reasoning.text: Formula from Full Bench: first charges on gross profits include depreciation, reserves, return on capital; surplus for bonus. Not applied here as loss.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Appellate Tribunal deviated from own formula by importing vague social justice.

court_reasoning.text: Workers' indiscipline and strike contributed to loss; cannot claim bonus linked to dividend from past reserves.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Social justice considerations irrelevant and untenable.

holdings.text: Workers not entitled to bonus if trading loss in the year; no right to reserves or past undistributed profits.
Bonus claim determined on profits of the year under claim; ordinarily no bonus if loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Millowners Association, Bombay v. Rashtreeya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Evolved formula for bonus: first charges on gross profits before surplus for bonus.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nizam Sugar Factory Ltd., Hyderabad v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus if loss in the year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Mills, Madhya Pradesh v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Bonus on basis of profits of the year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Famous Cine Laboratory v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Deprecates importing social justice outside formula; bonus only from current profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Supreme Court can interfere under Article 136 if arbitrary or unfair deal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Tribunals set up under it subject to Article 136.

outcome.summary: The appeal is allowed; decision of Labour Appellate Tribunal reversed and that of Industrial Court (Textiles and Hosiery), Kanpur restored. No bonus payable for 1949.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of Industrial Court's order denying bonus.

key_quotes.text: "Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies nature of bonus; only from current profits.

key_quotes.text: "If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Social justice is a very vague and indeterminate expression and no clear-cut definition can be laid down which will cover all the situations."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects vague social justice overriding profit-based formula.
